Hey Julian,

> Mostly, you are right. But sometimes it's valuable even to s=
how that
> something is possible - an "existence proof". E.g., it could be =
worth a
> paper to show that a particular paper could be represented by a n=
eural
> network. The paper could then describe the behaviour, the structure=
 of the
> network and (for completeness) the evolutionary method used to cr=
eate the
> network that displays this behaviour. Additional runs to verify =
that it can
> be done again might not actually add much to the paper, becau=
se that's not
> what the paper is about. (They might also not be attempted =
by the author
> because of the time it takes to run the experiment again, a=
nd an impending
> deadline.)

That's a good point, and I can think of at le=
ast one very good paper off the top of my head that does that. ["The Dynami=
cs of Active Categorical Perception in an Evolved Model Agent", Beer (2003)=
]. However, that was a good paper because it did an in-depth quantitative a=
nalysis of the agent's behavior. Lacking a quantitative analysis of the beh=
avior, the paper would likely be left wanting because ANN structure almost =
always tells us nothing about the algorithm underlying the behavior.


> In=
 general, I believe that there are many possible ways of doing good
> resea=
rch. The big problem with some papers is not that they don't follow
> some =
particular research methodology, rather that they are not clear about
> wha=
t they are seeking to show.

Well-put!


> Again, I agree to some extent. B=
ut you take for granted that what we are
> doing here is science. Much of w=
hat gets published in Gecco, CEC, TEC etc
> is not really science but rathe=
r engineering research, which can be good or
> bad. I think that comparing =
methods on some particular benchmark can be
> very valuable, but of course =
it helps if the benchmark is relevant.

Also a good point. If the goal is t=
o "make stuff," then methods papers with benchmarks make sense. However, be=
nchmarks require a quantitative comparison, so I don't think there's any es=
caping quantitative comparisons one way or the other.
